importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007, establishing himself as a top young talent in chess.
Naroditsky graduated from Stanford University with a bachelorâ€™s degree in history in 2019.
Naroditsky was hired as a chess columnist by The New York Times in 2022, marking a significant milestone in his media presence.
The 2025 US Chess Championship opened with a moment of silence for Naroditsky, highlighting his lasting impact on the chess community.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2007 to 2025 captures Naroditsky's rise from youth champion to a globally influential chess educator and commentator, including his peak online engagement and professional achievements.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at the age of 29.
He earned the grandmaster title before high school graduation and won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007.
Naroditsky taught chess through accessible content, gaining nearly half a million YouTube subscribers and 340,000 Twitch followers.
He was a regular contributor to Chess Life magazine and became a chess columnist for The New York Times in 2022.
The Charlotte Chess Center, where he served as head coach, and the International Chess Federation publicly mourned his death.
The 2025 US Chess Championship began with a moment of silence in his honor, underscoring his influence on the global chess community.
His family requested privacy following his death, and the community honored his legacy through educational outreach and remembrance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, a 29-year-old American chess grandmaster, has died, leaving behind a legacy as a top player, educator, and digital chess influencer. Born in the San Francisco Bay Area, he earned the grandmaster title before high school and won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in 2007. He became widely known through livestreamed games on YouTube and Twitch, building a massive global audience. Naroditsky also contributed to Chess Life and became a chess columnist for The New York Times. The Charlotte Chess Center, where he served as head coach, and the International Chess Federation publicly mourned his passing. The 2025 US Chess Championship began with a moment of silence in his honor, reflecting his deep impact on the chess community. His family has requested privacy, and his life is remembered for his passion, teaching, and ability to make chess accessible to all.
tags: mental health awareness (implied through sudden passing)
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
